yeah, since one year already xD
@Thunder: So not *super* hard.. probably the hardest thing is making the correct requests to download the video, the uploading to kopykate should be rather easy
You just need to place the file in your data-dir in kopykate, then edit the data.json of yours to contain that new file, sign through ZeroNet and finish.

@Thunder: I mean just copying videos from YouTube over to KopyKate without even asking for permission is kinda sh*t for the creators (ignoring the fact that they somewhat work for YouTube).
Also, for people who are new to ZeroNet it might just seem like they could just stay on the clearnet, because why start ZeroNet if I can just enter youtube.com into my address bar.. We just really need original content like @kopykate / @sylvaine (I believe is her new username) started with that series of hers.
@Thunder: This might even be the go-to way to get more people to join ZeroNet!
@Thunder: Yeah.! :D

@Thunder: Regarding the thought of using an already existing card game.. you could check out my [GitHub/da_cards-2](https://github.com/AnthyG/da_cards-2)..
It isn't at all finished, but it's (somewhat) peer 2 peer so quite a lot of stuff for client-side is already implemented, and as the server is written in nodejs, it shouldn't be that hard to re-write some stuff to use ZeroFrame I believe.

Though there are probably better more fleshed out card games written in JS already xD

Of course that still doesn't make the issue of how the stuff for transmitting and saving data etc. should be, go away.

Edit.:
And if that issue #1425 is going to be finished and @nofish: will approve it, then da_cards-2 might not even need a that big re-write other than to move all the server-side stuff to the client-side and somehow make it work..... xD

Getting a domain requires you to get some namecoins (NMC), not bitcoins (BTC) :D
You can also generate a domain, but that requires you to run a program, of which I have forgotten the name (so you tell it that you want e.g. `Hello` as a string, and it gives you `1HeLLo4uzjaLetFx6NH3PMwFP3qbRbTf3D`).

Zites are stored on your drive. Every zite you open. And all images, posts and what not as well. If you're a zite owner, you can mark files as optional, which means they won't be downloaded from other peers, until you actually want to view that file.
If you want to develop your own zite, you have to use Javascript, and the ZeroFrame-API, that is added to any new zite on creation.
The ZeroFrame-API is basically the communicator between the Python-Backend (ZeroFrame-Client) and the Javascript-Frontend (what the user can interact with etc.).

After all, you could probably just write code in any language and try and convert it to Javascript, but that's a bit stupid (IMO) :D
You could check out coffescript (which is what @nofish uses for the default zites like ZeroMe or ZeroMail) or use node and npm to create your zite (which is what @gitcenter, @krixano, I and probably a lot of other people do).

@Maxizrin: To mark files as optional, you have to add the property `optional` to the zites `content.json`-File. E.g.: `"optional": "(png/.*)",` would make all files in the sub-directory `png` optional (this is what I use for [ThunderWave](/thunderwave.bit/content.json) (you can see there, that there is a property called `files_optional`, that contains all optional files)).

Here's the link to the ZeroNet-Docs: http://zeronet.readthedocs.io/en/latest/site_development/zeroframe_api_reference/ (the code there is in coffeescript, but it's not that hard to translate to plain javascript)
@Schiz0: the zite admin can still moderate the content

I for my part added a 2-point long ruleset to ThunderWave (see cmd `/rules`), as I just don't want that anybody has to see any explicit content on the lobby (and that's pretty much the only place I can say that the rules apply for, because that's the literally only place I can actually know who posted what).

And I think that's a good compromise.
Just let your ZeroNet-Client run for some more time, that way you'll only download new stuff but upload a lot more to other users.
Yes! :D
